page.title: 12ACTON,WREXHAM
page.content: According to extracts from A.N. Palmer " History of Country Townships' of Wrexham". (1903) Acton has an area of about 889 acres. The name Acton derives from an English name ("Ac-tun") meaning "Oaktown". In 1202 Madoc ap Grufydd Maelor granted lands in "Hacton" to the monks of Valle Crucis. The largest area, some 700 acres in all, of the township of Acton belonged to the Acton Hall, the Home of the Jefferys family. Another extract from the history of Acton relates to the sale of Acton Hall to Sir Foster Cunliffe, a sale effected in April 1787. Sir Foster Cunliffe was a man of literary and refined tastes and high character. When the new road to Chester was built Sir Foster took advantage of the new boundaries to lay out and enclose Acton Park.
